page.title: International reactions to the 2011 Egyptian revolution

rev.diff:
Line 155: Line 155:
* {{flag|Australia}} â On 3 February, [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]] [[Julia Gillard]] announced "the time for change has come" and that "I absolutely condemn this violence."<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Prime Minister Julia Gillard calls for Egypt President Hosni Mubarak to stand down now|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/world/mubarak-supporters-clash-with-egyptian-opposition-protesters/story-e6frev00-1225999171589|date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|Australia}} â On 3 February, [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]] [[Julia Gillard]] announced "the time for change has come" and that "I absolutely condemn this violence."<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Prime Minister Julia Gillard calls for Egypt President Hosni Mubarak to stand down now|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/world/mubarak-supporters-clash-with-egyptian-opposition-protesters/story-e6frev00-1225999171589|date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|New Zealand}} â On 5 February [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (New Zealand)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Murray McCully]] condemned the violence against the protesters and expressed concern over the targeting of foreign journalists. "Reports that foreign journalists, including New Zealanders, have been targeted is extremely concerning and directly violates fundamental freedoms."<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Press release]]|title=McCully Condemns Violence Against Journalists in Egypt|url=http://feeds.beehive.govt.nz/release/mccully-condemns-violence-against-journalists-egypt?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+beehive-govt-nz%2Fportfolio%2Fforeign-affairs+%28Foreign+Affairs+-+beehive.govt.nz%29|publisher=[[Government Of New Zealand]]|accessdate=5 February 2011|work=|date=5 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|New Zealand}} â On 5 February [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (New Zealand)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Murray McCully]] condemned the violence against the protesters and expressed concern over the targeting of foreign journalists. "Reports that foreign journalists, including New Zealanders, have been targeted is extremely concerning and directly violates fundamental freedoms."<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Press release]]|title=McCully Condemns Violence Against Journalists in Egypt|url=http://feeds.beehive.govt.nz/release/mccully-condemns-violence-against-journalists-egypt?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+beehive-govt-nz%2Fportfolio%2Fforeign-affairs+%28Foreign+Affairs+-+beehive.govt.nz%29|publisher=[[Government Of New Zealand]]|accessdate=5 February 2011|work=|date=5 February 2011}}</ref>
â   â
==Non-governmental organisations==
  â
* The [[AFL-CIO]] supported the protests, saying that US President Barack Obama was not "on their side."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defenddemocracy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11792097&Itemid=348 |title=AFL-CIO Backs Egyptian Worker Protests, Says Obama Policies Not Clearly 'On Their Side' |publisher=Defenddemocracy.org |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref>
  â
* [[Salil Shetty]], head of [[Amnesty International]], believed Hosni Mubarak's decision to fire his cabinet would not stop the anti-government protests.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=205730 |title=Amnesty Int'l: Egypt Cabinet Firing Won't Quell Protests |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'') |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=3 February 2011}}<!--at late jan/early feb 2011, this particular link to jpost.com can be VERY slow to load. other jpost.com links load regulary.--></ref>
  â
* [[Hacktivist]] group [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] attacked multiple government websites and issued press releases calling for support of the Egyptian people.<ref>{{cite news|last=Emspak|first=Jesse|title=Egyptian Gov't Web Sites Under Attack|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/105329/20110126/egyptian-government-web-sites-attacked.htm|accessdate=27 January 2011|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=26 January 2011}}</ref>
  â
* Mohamed Abdel Dayem of the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] condemned police violence against journalists.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://cpj.org/2011/01/journalists-beaten-websites-blocked-amid-protests.php|title=Journalists Beaten, Websites Blocked Amid Protests in Egypt|publisher=[[Committee to Protect Journalists]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
  â
* [[Human Rights Watch]] said Egyptian police had escalated the use of force against largely peaceful demonstrations and called it "wholly unacceptable and disproportionate".<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html |title=Fresh Protests Erupt in Egypt â Army Reportedly on the Streets of Cairo as Curfew Is Imposed from 6 pm to 7 am Local Time|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref>
  â
* Militant Islamist group [[al-Qaeda]]'s Ayman al-Zawahiri said, "The constitution of the regime in Egypt claims that it is democratic. But it's truth that it's a suppressive regime that rules the people with suppressive forces and fake elections and corrupt media and unjust law."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Matthew Cole]]|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/al-qaeda-message-egypt/story?id=12951313 |title=Newly Released Al Qaeda Message Blasts Mubarak |work=[[abc news]] |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011}}</ref>
 
==Solidarity protests==
==Solidarity protests==
Line 184: Line 176:
On 9 February in [[Ukraine]], [[FEMEN]] activists organised a topless protest<ref>[http://femen.livejournal.com/136430.html FEMEN Livejournal, photos]</ref> in front of the Egyptian embassy in [[Kiev]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8144289-topless-femen-activist-supports-the-egyptian-revolution-at-the-egyptian-embassy-in-kiev-photos|title=Topless FEMEN activist Supports the Egyptian Revolution in kiev|date=9 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
On 9 February in [[Ukraine]], [[FEMEN]] activists organised a topless protest<ref>[http://femen.livejournal.com/136430.html FEMEN Livejournal, photos]</ref> in front of the Egyptian embassy in [[Kiev]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8144289-topless-femen-activist-supports-the-egyptian-revolution-at-the-egyptian-embassy-in-kiev-photos|title=Topless FEMEN activist Supports the Egyptian Revolution in kiev|date=9 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
==Non-governmental organisations==
  +
* The [[AFL-CIO]] supported the protests, saying that US President Barack Obama was not "on their side."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defenddemocracy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11792097&Itemid=348 |title=AFL-CIO Backs Egyptian Worker Protests, Says Obama Policies Not Clearly 'On Their Side' |publisher=Defenddemocracy.org |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref>
  +
* [[Salil Shetty]], head of [[Amnesty International]], believed Hosni Mubarak's decision to fire his cabinet would not stop the anti-government protests.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=205730 |title=Amnesty Int'l: Egypt Cabinet Firing Won't Quell Protests |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'') |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=3 February 2011}}<!--at late jan/early feb 2011, this particular link to jpost.com can be VERY slow to load. other jpost.com links load regulary.--></ref>
  +
* [[Hacktivist]] group [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] attacked multiple government websites and issued press releases calling for support of the Egyptian people.<ref>{{cite news|last=Emspak|first=Jesse|title=Egyptian Gov't Web Sites Under Attack|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/105329/20110126/egyptian-government-web-sites-attacked.htm|accessdate=27 January 2011|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=26 January 2011}}</ref>
  +
* Mohamed Abdel Dayem of the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] condemned police violence against journalists.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://cpj.org/2011/01/journalists-beaten-websites-blocked-amid-protests.php|title=Journalists Beaten, Websites Blocked Amid Protests in Egypt|publisher=[[Committee to Protect Journalists]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
  +
* [[Human Rights Watch]] said Egyptian police had escalated the use of force against largely peaceful demonstrations and called it "wholly unacceptable and disproportionate".<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html |title=Fresh Protests Erupt in Egypt â Army Reportedly on the Streets of Cairo as Curfew Is Imposed from 6 pm to 7 am Local Time|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref>
  +
* Militant Islamist group [[al-Qaeda]]'s Ayman al-Zawahiri said, "The constitution of the regime in Egypt claims that it is democratic. But it's truth that it's a suppressive regime that rules the people with suppressive forces and fake elections and corrupt media and unjust law."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Matthew Cole]]|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/al-qaeda-message-egypt/story?id=12951313 |title=Newly Released Al Qaeda Message Blasts Mubarak |work=[[abc news]] |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011}}</ref>
